text.p: Hewlett-Packard Co Monday announced new computer encoding technology which it said would meet government limits on exports.
The new plan, backed by partners Intel Corp and Microsoft Corp, could help minimise controversy over exports of computer hardware and software containing encryption features.
Under the plan, companies could export powerful encryption products with the encoding feature disabled to meet U.S. export controls.

The new plan "will exploit the full power of the Internet by addressing the security and data-integrity issues that have impaired and frightened users in the past," Hewlett-Packard Chairman Lewis Platt said in a statement.
The U.S. government has already approved the new technology.
HP said the government had concluded that the plan, called an international cryptography framework, "has sufficient technical controls to ensure compliance with U.S. policy."
Several other companies, including International Business Machines Corp, have also introduced new forms of encryption to meet U.S. export controls.

On Friday, President Clinton signed an executive order liberalizing such controls. Under the Clinton plan, companies may export stronger encryption than currently allowed if the products also provide a means for the government to decode the messages when acting under a court order or similar authorization. But the Clinton plan still would bar exports of powerful encryption that lacked the government access feature.
